instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-Awith no power. It has green light, no fan spin, and puls 0.027A from bench PSU.

I have no history, but It seams that someone already replaced <CAPACITOR>C7376</CAPACITOR>.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted (0.002 diode reading, and 0.1 ohm), and I have the same reading on L7130. All other big coils seams to have normal diode readings.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and check which side the short remains.
If all other big coils show good resistance to ground, then is safe to inject voltage.
As you have almost pure short (0.1 ohm), start with 1V; should be more thyan enough.
Use powerfull cables and set amp limit to max first (on PSU).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

It seams that both lines are shorted.

With F7140 removed, I get these values:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> = 0.002 on diode reading and 0.2 ohm to ground on both

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
This is 15" machine, has 2 (TWO) fuses; so remove both F7140/41.
I can't believe than need an explanation for this...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I thought it was necessary, but I also thought maybe there was a reason for it....

After removed both fuses, I've injected 2V and reached 5A but I can't see anything geting hot (strange but I can't see it).

However, I notice that <CAPACITOR>C7325</CAPACITOR> was missing, and the pad had exploded (<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>) It's not there, and was covered by UV glue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You may have short inside the board, between its copper layers.
If you are using 5A lab PSU, it may not inject anything; if gets in protection mode.
Start with 1V and increase voltage until get 4-4.5A.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I've started with 1V and finished with 2.30V and 4.6A of consume on PSU, but can't find anything geting hot...

 Should I scrap a little bit on the burnt pad of  <CAPACITOR>C7325</CAPACITOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Are you using powerfull cables?
The idea is to heat the bad component, not the cables.
IR camera available?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I'm using the same cables that I usually use, and with a IR cam.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
With aprox 9W you should be able to detect an hot spot.
Check with voltmeter if you realy get 2.3V on the board, when PSU shows 4.6A...
